unicode.value:
BEC 216 SOCIAL STUDIES IN EARLY CHILDHOOD

PURPOSE OF THE COURSE

Purpose

This course will help the learner to develop an understanding of methods, approaches, content, and resources for use in teaching social studies to young children.

COURSE DESCRIPTION

This course entails the definition of terms and concepts used in social studies, social interaction, and the learning environment of the pre-school child. It also entails resource materials and records.

TEACHING/LEARNING METHODOLOGIES

This course will be offered and/or undertaken through tutorials, group discussions, group and individual assignments, presentations, interactive questions and answers, micro-teaching lessons, peer teaching, and e-learning interactive forums. The learner will be required to go through this training module, make notes based on the objectives of the course, and attempt the questions given at the end of every lesson. Tutorial classes will be organized by the university where the lecturer will take the student through the course. The purpose of tutorials is to help the learner conceptualize the course. It is, therefore, important to study the module before attending the tutorials. Further reading in this area of the curriculum is encouraged. However, all information gathered should be within the course description and objectives.

COURSE ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION

Learning will be assessed through sit-in, Continuous Assessment Tests (CATs), Take Away Assignments, and a Main Examination. The CATs will constitute 30% and the Examination 70%.

MODULE ORGANIZATION

This module is organized in the form of lessons. In every lesson, an introduction is given. The introduction shows what the lesson constitutes. This is followed by the lesson objectives. Then, the learner is taken through the lesson content. The content may be sub-divided into sub-topics depending on the nature of the topic in a lesson. A summary of what has been learned is given. At the end of the lesson, the learner is given activities. These activities are in the form of questions and/or practical exercises. It is good to note that this is not a textbook. The content is therefore in the form of lecture notes. Further reading from textbooks is recommended. A list of books to refer to is given at the end of the module.

Course content

Definition of social studies and related terms, meaning and scope of social studies, methods and approaches of teaching social studies, methods and approaches of teaching social studies, pedagogical theories related to social studies in Early Childhood, content and resources for use in teaching social studies to young children, activities for social studies in Early Childhood.

Course objectives

  1. Define social studies
  2. Discuss the meaning and scope of social studies.
  3. Explain the methods and approaches of teaching social studies in Early Childhood.
  4. Discuss the content and identify resources for use in teaching social studies to young children.
  5. Discuss the pedagogical theories related to social studies in Early Childhood.
  6. Identify activities for social studies involved in early childhood education in different social environments.

Lesson 1: SOCIAL STUDIES

Introduction

Objectives

By the end of the lesson, students should be able to:

  1. Define terms related to social studies in early childhood
  2. Describe types of socialization
  3. Discuss the objectives of teaching social studies

The term social refers to society. Social studies refer to the study of society. It encompasses the learning about social interaction with people and their environment. Children interact with teachers, pupils, and the environment. (KI.E 2006-2008)

Social studies can also refer to the study of issues affecting the life of an individual in society. It is the study of people living in a society or organization. It involves activities that will make an individual familiar with the environment so that she/he enhances social skills for appropriate social relationships and interaction with the environment.

A broad definition of social studies focuses on the study of people in terms of:

  1. How they relate with one another
  2. How they relate with the environment
  3. How they control diversities in the environment
  4. How the physical environment controls people

This definition of social studies tends to focus on the life of an individual in the family and community as they interact with the physical environment. This simplification of social studies enables the child to understand who he or she is in the context of the social and physical environment.

Socialization

It involves learning and performing behaviors expected of them by society for survival and working together through interaction. One learns behavior, one learns about his or her culture, and how to live within it. An individual gains skills and habits necessary for acting and taking part within their society. Society orientates the members to its moral norms, attitude values, motives, social roles, language, and symbols that ensure the continuity of social aspects and culture.

Types of socialization

Primary socialization

This occurs from birth to adolescence and is usually imposed by immediate family members or those close to the child at this stage.

Secondary socialization

It is the ongoing process of learning one goes through to adjust to new situations. Secondary socialization differs from primary socialization in that adults bring to the new situation the accumulated knowledge of their previous experiences, for example, experiences achieved from a formal setting like schools, training to receive professional know-how.

Anticipatory socialization

This refers to training in skills and values that is oriented towards a new role that one will enter in the future.

Re-socialization

It is associated with learning that takes place in institutions such as prisons or mental hospitals where members re-learn the social norms of society.

Community

It is a deliberately organized group of people in a given location sharing common facilities, resources, interests, aspirations, and solidarity for the purpose of a common future. A community is interconnected, interdependent, and often has similar values and aims. It is a group that has a life of its own apart from the life of each member.

Environment

The external conditions and surroundings that people live in. It’s made up of social, cultural issues, man-made and natural features which can positively or negatively affect individuals. It is divided into two: Physical and social environment.

Physical environment

It is the geography of a place, and therefore, children should be taught to function and live in the physical environment. This means they need to have mastered the craft of their physical environment.

Social environment

This has to do with the language, culture, beliefs, history, and traditions of a community. Children are expected to have mastery of the language of their community and understand the significance of the cultural practices and rites of passage. These oral traditions were passed on through proverbs, role-play, imitation, dances, direct instructions, riddles, songs, ceremonies, and stories.

Society

It’s a group of people in an organized community or structured institutions with common aims and interests. It’s a group of people bound by cultural identity, social solidarity, and functional interdependence. Human societies have patterns of interrelationships between individuals that share unique cultures or institutions. Individuals are allowed to achieve their needs or wishes that they can’t achieve when alone.

COMMUNITY

It is made up of people with families and is also made up of institutions. Ethnic groups form a community. The child should identify the neighborhood institutions, e.g., church, school, health center, and they should be guided to know the people in these places, the work they do, and the equipment they use.

Country

It is made up of different communities, and children should know their community and others. They should be helped to interact with and conserve their cultural heritage. They should know the president, national anthem, the flag, etc. The teacher should guide them in songs, poems, naming people, society structure, role-play of people’s jobs, drawing, coloring, and pictures related to society.

Objectives of social studies in ECD curriculum

Social studies deal with people’s interaction within the environment. From the beginning, children are put in a social setup. They interact with the social and physical environment. They face challenges adjusting to the environment due to little knowledge of environmental concepts, limited skills, and an inability to explain their immediate environment. Social studies address their limitations and egocentric nature.

Through social studies, a child should be able to do the following:

  1. Familiarize themselves with the surrounding environment through nature walks, observation, clips, also by identifying, naming, using, and associating with the immediate environment.
  2. Accept the surrounding environment and cultural heritage and strive to conserve them. They can do this by making sisal skirts, toys, ropes, singing local community songs.
  3. Use things found within the environment properly. This should be done using elements of nature constructively. These include trees, flowers, rivers, plants, animals, etc. They should only use what they need and leave the rest intact.
  4. Develop observational and discovery skills. Children prefer living creatures to dead ones. The teacher can plan educational trips for them to experience, observe, and discover things in their natural setup, e.g., the museum.
  5. Acquire acceptable health habits and maintain good habits through eating a balanced diet, adequate exercise, and rest. This is done by ensuring that they wash their hands after using the toilet, use a handkerchief to blow their nose. Ensure they eat a balanced diet by advising their parents. Encourage them in physical activities for body exercise. For the young ones, provide rest time in the afternoon.
  6. Appreciate interaction with other people in the environment. When children join preschool or class one, they join a new social environment. They need to be guided and engaged in activities that will bond them to their new surroundings. They can express their needs, feelings, and emotions. Resource people should be invited from nearby, and children should ask them questions. The children should appreciate other people’s talents, e.g., those with the talents of playing musical instruments, composing poems, etc. At school, they interact with teachers, peers, and new friends. The teacher can engage them in songs, new games, role-play, and they should appreciate the teacher or pupil who wins the game.
  7. Identify life skills required in environmental awareness. It involves the ability to control oneself, decision-making, problem-solving, and making choices. The teacher should tell stories or use role-play to help them develop such skills. They should acquire skills that can be used to organize and address the environment. This involves field visits, theme walks, nature walks, singing songs, reciting poems on specific concepts learned from the environment, e.g., they can compose a song on flowers, trees, rivers, etc.

Activity

  1. Define the terms:
    1. Social studies
    2. Society
    3. Community
    4. Social environment
    5. Physical environment
  2. Discuss the objectives of teaching social studies in ECE.

LESSON 2: Importance of social studies

Objectives

By the end of the lesson, students should be able to:

  1. Discuss the importance of social studies in the ECE curriculum.
  2. Describe the nature and scope of social studies.
  3. Describe types of families.
  4. Discuss the roles of families.

Social studies is a key area of study in ECE, as mentioned in Lesson 1. It:

  1. Creates awareness and understanding of the children’s environment and appreciation of it because children are adventurers and love experimenting, so they are natural explorers. Teachers should use the immediate environment to help them learn.
  2. Helps to develop a sense of belonging, being mindful of others, accepting others’ views, and becoming aware of factors that affect their surroundings.
  3. Children learn about their cultural values and appreciate cultural heritage through listening to stories, riddles, proverbs, poems, and so on. They also learn to appreciate other people’s cultures through oral literature or social interaction at school.
  4. Through role-play, which is a major teaching and learning activity in social studies, they develop positive attitudes towards work, different people, dress, and different kinds of foods.
  5. Develop positive attitudes towards animals after observing them during a visit or trip.
  6. Enables children to acquire desirable social, civic, and personal behavior important for social and individual education. This social learning enables the child to function in a given society.
  7. Helps the child to be a problem-solver, especially in solving personal, social, and environmental problems. Problem-solving helps the child to be creative and critical in matters pertaining to life. Through problem-solving, the child can also meet the demands of a challenging society.

Nature and scope of social studies

The child, being a member of society, needs to understand society’s structure, starting from organization and leadership. The structure of society starts from the child (smallest unit) to the country (largest unit). Children are born into families, which are members of social communities (churches, clubs, schools, institutions, and markets).

Structure of societies

As members of society, children should be able to know family members by name and other people in the home. They should understand their home well, i.e., food eaten, buildings at their home, furniture, domestic animals, clothes, utensils, among others. The teacher can ask them to draw and color family members or the food eaten, color the buildings, utensils, among others. They can also role-play family members' work. Be familiar with neighborhoods, local institutions, the president of the country, the national anthem, the national flag, and colors. To understand the neighborhood, they can take neighborhood walks, role-play family work, sing songs, and recite poems, etc.

FAMILY

Nuclear family

It is made up of a father, mother, and children (biological or adopted). The teacher should help the children know relations' names, e.g., mother, father, brother, sister; family residence; survival requirements, e.g., food, water, clothing, medical care, etc. They should know the role of each member. The nuclear family lives together unless separated due to economic or work reasons.

Extended family

Made up of other relatives and the nuclear family. They may share the same compound but live in different houses. The children should know the relatives' names, e.g., grandparents, uncles, aunts, cousins, etc., and address the older people respectfully in the extended family.

Single parent

May be made up of a father or mother and children. They live together and share resources. The children should be guided to know family members' roles, foods eaten, clothes worn, tools or utensils used, and respect for the parent should be instilled.

Polygamous family

A family with one husband and more than one wife. They may share a homestead, or some wives may stay far away. Each wife has her own house with her children. Children should be able to know relationship names, e.g., half-brother, half-sister, stepmother. Teachers should teach respect for family members.

Child-headed family

Contemporary issues in society have led to this kind of family. It consists of children alone. The elder sibling takes the role of the parent and organizes the younger ones. This family comes into existence due to many factors, e.g., death of parents due to HIV/AIDS, divorce, or when the extended family bond has broken.

Functions of the family

  • Reproduction: For a society to maintain itself, it must be able to replace its dying members; therefore, the family contributes to the survival of the human race through its function of reproduction.
  • Protection: Infants need constant care and economic security; therefore, the need to have a familiar environment since they are dependent on adults. It is the ultimate responsibility of adults to protect and bring up children in a responsible environment. Children are part of the community, i.e., they begin their social life by acquiring the status their family has instilled in them.
  • Socialization: Parents and other key persons in the family monitor a child’s behavior. They also transmit appropriate norms, values, attitudes, and language to the child; therefore, the family becomes the first and most important socialization agent for a child.
  • Regulation of sexual behaviors: Sexual norms are subject to change over time depending on the culture of that particular family, but whatever the time or period, cultural values in a society's standards of sexual behavior are more likely to be defined within the family circle. The structure of society influences these standards so that, characteristically, in male-dominated societies, formal and informal norms permit men to express and enjoy their sexual desires more freely than women.
  • Affection and companionship: Ideally, the family provides warmth and intimate relationships that help children feel satisfied and secure. Unlike other social institutions like schools and churches, the family is obligated to serve the emotional needs of its members, to understand one another, to care for each other, and to be there when a need arises.
  • Provision of social status: Children inherit social positions because of their family background and the reputation of their parents and siblings. The family unit presents a newborn child with an ascribed status of race and ethnicity that helps determine his or her place within a society (stratification systems). Family resources affect children’s ability to pursue certain opportunities, especially in education. Therefore, a family has the responsibility to fulfill several functions, for example, providing religious training, education, and recreational outlets. Although other social institutions have gradually assumed many of these functions, the family remains the most important landmark in a child’s development and growth.

Activity

  1. Distinguish the different types of families in your locality and discuss the roles of various family members.
  2. Show how the above relates to the study of society in ECE.

Leadership and Organization

🎯 Learning Objectives

  • Define leadership.
  • Discuss types of traditional and modern leadership.
  • Assess the contribution of leadership in the teaching of social studies in Early Childhood Education (ECE).

Defining Leadership

Leadership is the deliberate influence of others within an organization or system to achieve objectives. It can be expressed through verbal or non-verbal communication, influencing feelings, thoughts, views, and behaviors to motivate action.

Types of Leadership

  • Status Leadership: Leadership based on a designated position or title.
  • Emergent Leadership: Leadership that arises organically from within a group, often from individuals not holding formal leadership positions. For instance, in a family without parents present, older siblings might naturally assume leadership roles.

Leadership in Social Studies

Social studies explores organization and leadership at different societal levels:

  • Family (nuclear, extended, single-parent, child-headed)
  • Neighborhood, school, local administration
  • Country and president

Within families, leadership involves providing basic necessities, recreational opportunities, and nurturing through interaction. Teachers can facilitate learning about family leadership through role-playing activities, songs, and poems.

The School as a Social System

Schools function as miniature societies within larger society, deliberately designed for cultural transmission. This process enables individuals to integrate into societal norms and interact predictably. Although other social agents like religion and clubs also contribute, schools play a critical role in a child's development and preparation for societal participation.

Historically, traditional African education, often gender-segregated, emphasized clan values and practical skill development through apprenticeship (e.g., blacksmithing, herbalism, midwifery, marksmanship). The introduction of Western formal education significantly altered these traditional structures.

School Leadership

School leadership includes the head teacher, deputy head teacher, teaching staff, and support staff. Teachers can organize classroom working groups and student leadership positions. The head teacher holds overall responsibility, supported by the deputy and senior teachers.

Head Teacher Responsibilities

  • Student welfare
  • Curriculum oversight
  • Staff coordination
  • Resource management (human and material)
  • Regular communication with parents and higher authorities (emails, letters, meetings, newsletters, AGMs, PTAs, etc.)

Leadership Styles

Democratic Leadership:
Values free expression, consultation, and consensus among members. Promotes high morale and encourages initiative but can sometimes slow down decision-making processes.
Laissez-faire Leadership:
Characterized by a "hands-off" approach, allowing substantial freedom. While potentially fostering creativity, it can lead to chaos and hinder the achievement of institutional goals.
Autocratic Leadership:
Emphasizes control and dictates decisions. Can ensure quick action and maintain order.
  • Advantages:
    • Commands respect and facilitates quick decisions.
    • Enhances control and efficiency in a structured environment.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Suppresses creativity and initiative among members.
    • Creates a climate of fear and can lead to high staff turnover.
    • Reduces overall morale and loyalty among team members.
Charismatic Leadership:
Relies on the leader's personality, charm, and ability to inspire. Can be highly effective in motivating followers.
  • Advantages:
    • Can effectively drive towards institutional goals through inspiration.
    • Fosters a sense of unity and shared purpose.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Success is heavily dependent on the leader's continued popularity and can be short-lived.
    • Can stifle dissenting opinions as followers prioritize loyalty to the leader.
    • May prioritize image over substance, leading to disillusionment if the leader's flaws become apparent.

Traditional Forms of Government

Pre-colonial African societies exhibited diverse political systems, from councils of elders to chiefdoms and kingdoms. These systems can be categorized into:

  • Non-centralized States: Lacking a single, overarching leader, these systems relied on clan structures and established customs for social control (e.g., Sukuma of Tanzania, Ibos of Nigeria, Kikuyu of Kenya, Tallensi of Ghana).
  • Centralized States: Organized under a powerful sovereign leader (king or queen), supported by law enforcement and a structured legal system (e.g., Asante of Ghana, Yoruba of Nigeria, Zulus of South Africa, Barotse of Zambia, Baganda of Uganda).

The Khoisan

The Khoisan exemplify a clan-based system. Clans were organized by seniority, with the senior clan's head serving as the community chief. Chieftainship was hereditary. A council of elders, composed of other clan heads, collaborated with the chief to maintain order and ensure justice.

Polygamy was common, with marriage occurring early (boys at 14, girls at 12). This practice limited children's opportunities to mature fully before entering adulthood. However, children did have opportunities for play and self-decoration during recreational periods.

The Community in ECE

Early Childhood Development education, extending into lower primary (ages 6-8), emphasizes understanding community organization and leadership. Children learn to identify their town, village, local landmarks (police station, health center, etc.). In lower primary, this expands to understanding administrative divisions (sub-location, location, division, district), administrative titles, and boundaries. They learn to identify local leaders, such as the sub-location head, chief, and District Officer (D.O.).

Teaching Methods in Social Studies

Social studies concepts are learned through environmental interaction:

  • Observation: Watching and learning from others.
  • Imitation/Modeling: Copying observed behaviors.
  • Observational Learning: Learning by observing consequences and interactions.

Children observe and imitate behaviors seen at home, in media (TV, films), and in real-life situations. By carefully observing children's play and listening to their conversations, teachers can gain valuable insights into their lives and experiences.

✍️ Practice Activity

  1. Describe the different types of leadership exhibited in your community.
  2. What are the advantages of each type of leadership you described?

📚 Key Takeaways

  • Leadership involves influencing others to achieve shared goals.
  • Various leadership styles exist, each with its own strengths and weaknesses.
  • Understanding community structures and leadership is an important component of social studies education.

Methods and Approaches of Teaching Social Studies in ECE

Objectives

By the end of the lesson, students should be able to:

  • Describe five methods of teaching social studies in ECE.
  • Discuss the benefits of each method.
  • Describe the steps to follow when planning for an ECE observational trip.

Introduction

Various approaches are used in teaching social studies in ECE. They include:

  • Observational trips
  • Modeling
  • Demonstration
  • Role play
  • Storytelling

Observational Trips

Observational trips allow young children to explore and observe their environment. These trips provide concrete experiences or first-hand information that cannot be found in pictures, books, or printed materials. They help children use multiple senses, relate theory to reality, and make concepts meaningful.

Types of Observational Trips

1. Theme Walk

During a theme walk, the teacher gives students guided information on what to observe in the school compound. This can include observing buildings, the staffroom, library, and offices. The teacher asks guiding questions to focus on specific learning objectives, listens to conversations to clarify wrong concepts, and answers questions.

Teachers can also plan neighborhood trips to explore the surroundings, familiarize students with their environment, and apply concepts. Safety is emphasized, such as walking carefully to avoid hazards and not provoking insects. After the trip, the teacher will display collected materials and organize follow-up activities, such as:

  • Drawing and coloring collected objects
  • Grouping objects by shape, size, or color
  • Engaging in songs or reciting poems about the trip
  • Displaying drawings and artwork in a designated area to build self-esteem

2. Specific and Purposeful Observational Trips

This type of trip has specific objectives. For example, a trip to a river might have objectives like:

  • Naming the river
  • Identifying sources of water
  • Discussing uses of the water
  • Exploring inappropriate uses of the water/river

Specific questions should be prepared to meet these objectives, and follow-up activities, like drawing and coloring the river, should be included.

3. Major Field Trips

Major field trips address several learning objectives and may include visits to museums, zoos, animal orphanages, musical festivals, theaters, and airports. These trips often involve multiple classes and meet the needs of different age groups.

Conducting a Major Trip

Steps to conducting a major trip include:

  • Planning the trip
  • Undertaking the trip
  • Organizing follow-up activities

Planning the Trip

Planning a trip involves several considerations:

  • Decision-making: Choose an appropriate location based on objectives and age suitability.
  • Selecting the location: Ensure the location is safe, interesting, and close enough to avoid fatigue.
  • Pre-visit: The teacher should pre-visit the site to meet employees, understand rules, and plan logistics.
  • Preparation for children and parents: Inform parents, secure commitments, and provide details of the trip.
  • Assigning duties: Define roles for supervision, first aid, snack distribution, etc.

Taking the Trip

On the day of the trip, assemble participants, conduct a roll call, and distribute name tags. Remind students of rules, answer questions, and engage them with thought-provoking questions to guide learning. Simplify the guide’s information for children, and thank helpers at the end of the visit.

Follow-Up Activities

Organize follow-up activities, such as:

  • Drawing, painting, and coloring
  • News telling, reciting poems, and singing songs
  • Modeling and role-playing

Modeling

Role modeling enables children to acquire new behaviors by observing others, aligning with humanistic and social learning theories. Albert Bandura’s social learning theory states that learning occurs through observation.

Factors Influencing Observational Learning

  • Relationship between the role model and learners
  • Relevance of the modeled behavior
  • Ability of learners to imitate the model
  • Motivation of learners

The teacher should model desired behaviors, such as consistent thoughts, positive attitude, warmth, and respect for learners.

Role Play

Role play involves students imitating real-life situations. This method fosters skills like communication, social competence, and understanding societal roles. Teachers should guide students, correct errors carefully to maintain self-esteem, and provide activities that reinforce the role play experience.

Demonstration

Demonstration is a practical approach to teaching. The teacher or a student shows a process or operation to illustrate how something works.

Ways to Ensure Successful Demonstrations

  • Conduct a trial run of the demonstration
  • Ensure all students have a clear view
  • Engage students in the demonstration
  • Follow a logical sequence of steps

Advantages of Demonstration

  • Cost-effective in terms of time and resources
  • Provides accurate results
  • Allows for real-time clarification

Disadvantages of Demonstration

  • Students may be passive
  • Not all students may participate

Storytelling Method

In storytelling, the teacher engages students by narrating stories to teach concepts. This can be made more child-centered by using questions, discussions, dramatizations, or visual aids.

Suitable Topics for Storytelling

  • Domestic and wild animals
  • Roles of family members
  • Cultural ceremonies
  • Eating habits

Exploration and Discovery

Exploration involves children observing and interacting with their surroundings, while discovery involves learning through finding new information. These methods build confidence and encourage holistic development.

Teacher’s Role in Learning through Discovery

  • Setting specific, measurable objectives
  • Encouraging interest in learning
  • Providing safe environments for exploration
  • Helping children develop skills such as concentration and observation

Social Studies Resources for Teaching

Objectives

By the end of the lesson, students should be able to:

  • Describe the criteria for selection of instructional media for social studies in ECE.
  • Discuss types of instructional media for social studies in ECE.
  • Discuss methods of sourcing instructional media for social studies in ECE.

Introduction

Children should interact with materials to acquire skills, ask questions, and receive answers. Teachers should facilitate social interaction and curiosity. Well-prepared materials encourage children to practice familiar skills and tackle new challenges.

Selection Criteria for Social Studies Materials

Planning for social studies lessons should include identifying activities, collecting materials, and conducting activities to achieve lesson objectives.

Guidelines for Selecting Materials

  • Safety: Avoid materials with rough edges, sharp corners, or small parts that children may ingest. Ensure cleanliness.
  • Durability: Choose long-lasting materials like plastic or hard wood to reduce costs.
  • Function: Ensure materials are in working condition and can be manipulated by children.
  • Relevance: Materials should match the concepts or skills to be taught and be age-appropriate.
  • Appearance: Use attractive materials with different colors, shapes, and textures to sustain interest.
  • Variety: Provide various materials to allow freedom of choice and cater to different learning needs.
  • Versatility: Use multipurpose materials that develop multiple skills, like language, math, or social studies concepts.

Care of Materials

To ensure materials last, teachers should model responsibility. Some care methods include:

  • Storing materials according to type, such as washable, dustable, or laminated items.
  • Using stain repellents or stitching to preserve materials like dolls or puppets.
  • Sanding rough edges and painting wooden items for durability and ease of cleaning.
  • Repairing damaged items promptly to avoid further wear and costs.

Sourcing Materials for Social Studies

Teachers should use real materials, or realia, which are effective in teaching. Materials can be gathered by teachers and students and displayed in various learning centers.

Examples of Social Studies Materials

  • Charts: Large sheets displaying information, typically made from durable materials like manila or polythene sheets.
  • Flash Cards: Small, durable cards for matching activities, made with visible text and durable materials like old plastics.
  • Picture Cards: Pictures glued onto cardboard, covered with clear polythene for protection.
  • Thematic Picture Books: Collections of topic-related images organized in a book, useful for storytelling.
  • Chalkboard: An essential teaching tool, used for drawings and student engagement in class illustrations.
  • Puppets: Sock or string puppets that stimulate creativity and storytelling.
  • Models: Physical representations of objects, created with materials like clay or papier-mâché.

Types of Instructional Resources for Pre-School Social Studies

Instructional resources are vital for helping children understand social studies concepts, fostering engagement, and making abstract ideas concrete. These resources include:

1. Reading Materials

Reading materials help children learn various skills and concepts. Examples include:

  • Books: Must cater to individual differences, including reading disabilities and visual impairments.
  • Newspapers: Provide awareness of current events in the physical and social environment.
  • Magazines: Broaden children's knowledge with topics on environment, animals, and plants.

2. Audio-Visual Resources

Audio-visual materials enhance learning through sensory engagement, including:

  • Realia: Real specimens from the environment.
  • Artifacts: Cultural objects like gourds or sculptures.
  • Photographs and Pictures: Visual aids that help explain societal and environmental concepts.
  • Cartoons: Simple, humorous illustrations that convey ideas effectively.
  • Globes and Maps: Tools for teaching location, direction, and distance.
  • Media Programs: Educational programs on radio, television, and videos.

3. Community Resources

Community resources can be integrated into the classroom through:

  • Creating a social studies corner with materials from the local environment.
  • Field trips to community sites.
  • Inviting guest speakers.
  • Using audio-visual materials that depict community experiences.

The Social Studies Corner

This is a designated classroom area where relevant materials for social studies are displayed. It is the teacher's responsibility to ensure these materials are useful and educational.

Activity

  1. Identify locally available materials for teaching social studies in your school.
  2. Choose a social studies theme and list materials that would support instruction for that theme.
